Sorry, I just realized how unclear I was.  I haven't updated breve
recently=
 because of legacy code.
There might be more than one NEAT biped on youtube=
!  I was referring
to this one http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3D5JFptXxRLVE=
&NR=3D1
And if you wouldn't mind I could use the shell script as well.  I r=
un
a Linux cluster but generally develop on a Windows machine, so I will
ma=
ke a .bat.
Thanks in advance,
ck

n Kowall"
<coolbeanskowall@...> wrote:
>
> Yes, I would like the code!  I h=
ave been stalling on making the
> upgrades past breve 2.5 i.e. not really u=
sing the new python
> capabilities, simply because Klein deprecated the dat=
a class. 
> Progress has a way of dragging us forward!  What type of experi=
ments?
>  Are you the guys with the learning bipedal walker on you tube?
> =
ck
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Cesar G. Miguel" <cesar.gomes@> wrote:
>=
 >
> > Peter B. and I have been doing some experiments with Breve using the=

> > NEAT-Python implementation. It's not a plugin, though. You have to set=

> > up a fitness function that calls the Breve engine from the command
> >=
 line and passes the chromosomes by argument. Once the Breve simulation
> >=
 is finished, it returns the fitness for each individual.
> > 
> > So it's =
a two-step problem: first set-up your environment within
> > Breve, as you'=
d do in a normal experiment; then you define a fitness
> > function to load=
 that environment every time you need to evaluate the
> > population. Think=
 of Breve as the "evaluator" and not part of NEAT.
> > It's a completely se=
parated module.
> > 
> > If you have interest, we can send you the code. It=
 only works in linux
> > right now, given that you need to use some shell s=
cripts. But I think
> > it won't be hard to translate that into a bat file.=

> > 
> > Cesar
> > 
> > On Thu, Jul 10, 2008 at 11:20 AM, Correy Allen Kow=
all
> > <coolbeanskowall@> wrote:
> > > Does anyone know of a NEAT or hyper=
NEAT plugin for the breve
> > > simulation engine? If not, I will write one=
, if someone points me
> > > toward the most solid and lightweight c/c++ ve=
rsion.
> > > ck
> > >
> > >
